awd_titl_txt: Exploring Electronic Response Properties of Molecules and Extended Systems using Theoretical Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) and Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods (CTMC) Programs of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jochen Autschbach of the University at Buffalo, State University of New York and his research team develop and apply quantum theory-based methods in order to learn how light (also known as electromagnetic radiation) can be used to determine the structure of molecules and the internal motions of their atoms and electrons.  The Autschbach group is focusing specifically on nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy and Raman spectroscopy.  NMR spectroscopy is a cousin of the magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) technology used in medical diagnostics, and utilizes strong magnetic fields and radio-frequency light to reveal the structure of molecules.  In Raman spectroscopy, light (often of visible or ultraviolet wavelengths) is scattered off molecules, and slight changes in the wavelength of the scattered light can provide clues to the vibrational motions of molecules and their overall structure. With the help of sophisticated calculations and computer simulations, the outcome of experimental measurements of these molecular properties are predicted and analyzed. This research advances our understanding of the relationships between molecular structure and measured properties of molecules, as well as our general understanding of the interaction of electromagnetic radiation and matter. Theoretical methods and software developed during this investigation are made available to the larger community of scientists. In addition, this research project provides in-depth training of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as opportunities for summer internships of high-school students. The student experience is enhanced by the collaborative nature of the project: While the research in the PI's laboratory is theoretical and computational in nature, it is carried out in the context of collaborations with experimental researchers from a variety of fields including materials science and catalysis. 

The molecular properties in question are observed in spectroscopic or optical measurements and of high practical importance to learn about the structures and functions of molecules. The theoretical support provided by the PI is crucial in order to establish and refine the underlying structure-property relationships. Specifically, the properties of interest determine the nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and the optical activity of molecules. The theoretical efforts of the project focus specifically on solid-state NMR parameters, NMR relaxation phenomena, and the structural and electronic origins of natural electronic and vibrational optical activity. In addition, the influence of the chemical and physical environment on these molecular properties is explored. NMR relaxation contains a wealth of information about the dynamics and characteristic correlation times of a chemical system. The PI studies the relaxation with ab-initio (from first principles) molecular dynamics simulations, which makes it possible to investigate systems containing elements from all across the periodic table. The optical activity-related part of the project focuses on resonance-effects in Raman vibrational optical activity, that is, when the Raman laser wavelength coincides with an electronic excitation wavelength, and on circularly polarized luminescence. Calculations of solid-state NMR parameters are undertaken to learn how they may reveal the unknown structures of chemical catalysts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this research project we use high-performance computing together with quantum theory to calculate how molecules and nano-scale systems interact with light or electric and magnetic fields. The project also requires computational predictions of how molecules react with each other. The calculations tell us how the electrons in a molecule respond to the presence of light and other types of fields, which is why the word 'response' appears in the project title. The interactions of the molecules with the light or fields underpin science's most powerful experimental tools for revealing the chemical bonding in molecules, their geometric shapes, and how the bonding and molecular shapes change during chemical reactions.

The intellectual merit of the research project is the theoretical prediction of molecular interactions with electromagnetic fields. In the project, this is applied to important types of molecules for which the arrangements of atoms and chemical bonds are not known or contested, but need to be known urgently. Another facet of the research is explaining experimental observations to confirm that they are properly understood and interpreted. A third aspect is to develop a better fundamental understanding of molecule - field interactions, i.e. what makes them strong or weak? Why does an observed effect have a certain sign and not the other? A fourth aspect is building confidence in the theoretical calculations to the point that reliable predictions of new physico-chemical phenomena can be made.

The project also has made significant progress toward the computational prediction of dynamic phenomena in liquid phase systems that can be probed by an experimental technique called nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR), which probes the response of atoms and molecules to magnetic fields. We perform dynamic simulations of liquid systems, such as solutions of sodium chloride in water. The dynamic behavior of the water molecules surrounding the sodium and chloride ions is then reflected in the NMR signals of the ions, such as in the widths of the observed spectral lines. This part of the project has progressed through the early development stages, in the sense that new theoretical and computational methods have been developed for calculating the line widths, and they have been shown to reproduce experimental data for a variety of systems across a large range of conditions (different pressures and temperature). Now, these new computational methods are ready to be applied to systems of broad interest in chemistry.

The broader impacts of the project are as follows: As part of the project, new theoretical methods were developed for calculating interactions between molecules and electromagnetic fields, and to improve the accuracy of such calculations. These are available to other researchers and the public in the free open-source quantum chemistry package NWChem (https://nwchemgit.github.io/) of which the principal investigator (PI) is a co-developer, and in other quantum chemistry software packages. Our developments of new theoretical methods contribute to the scientific software infrastructure in general and are used by chemists, bio-chemists, physicists, and material scientists. Some of our research has implications for bio-medical research, catalysis, and materials research. In-depth training in science, technology, engineering, and mathematical (STEM) fields is widely recognized as a crucial asset for any advanced nation in the 21st century. Crucial parts of the training of a research scientist are 'hands-on', by observing experienced researchers and interacting with them. The PI and his group contribute actively to this endeavor, by training next generation scientists in the laboratory and by providing research experiences for undergraduate students. Furthermore, the PI's outreach and his numerous contributions to the chemical education literature help to train the next generation of scientists as well as school teachers who educate our children.

During the period of this grant, the PI published a quantum theory textbook for beginners and more experienced students and researchers (Oxford University Press, 2020). The book features several chapters that are strongly influenced by the research carried out under this grant and its predecessors. Together with a postdoctoral researcher who worked on the project, the PI co-wrote another textbook, on the topic of molecular orbitals (American Chemical Society, 2023). This book can be considered as a primer on this important topic, which underlies chemists' understanding of molecular properties, reactivity, and their response to fields.
